P: Typical early-career stress. I like the work. I do worry about work-life balance and sometimes about being…a little too solo.
D: Understood. I’ll check your vitals and do a quick neuro exam.
P: Sure.
D: Blood pressure and heart rate look good. Neuro exam is normal—strength, sensation, reflexes, coordination, and eye movements are all intact.
P: That’s good to hear.
D: Based on what you’ve shared, this fits episodic migraine with visual aura. No red flags, so we don’t need imaging right now.
P: Works for me. I’d rather not pay for a fancy picture unless we need one.
D: Fair. Let’s talk plan. We’ll build two parts: a fast-acting treatment for attacks, and a preventive to reduce how often they happen.
P: Sounds like a policy memo. Acute and long-term.
D: Exactly. For acute therapy, I’d suggest a triptan. Rizatriptan 10 mg at onset—take it as soon as the aura starts or the pain begins. You can repeat once in two hours if needed, max 30 mg in 24 hours. It works better paired with an NSAID like naproxen 500 mg.
P: Okay. Any “gotchas”?
D: Don’t use it more than about 8–9 days a month to avoid rebound. Don’t use triptans if you have heart disease or uncontrolled blood pressure—you don’t. If nausea hits, metoclopramide 10 mg helps.
P: What about the newer meds? Gepants?
D: Ubrogepant or rimegepant are good and don’t constrict blood vessels. Effective and well tolerated. They’re pricier and insurance sometimes pushes triptans first. We can switch if triptans don’t work or you can’t tolerate them.
P: Let’s start with the affordable option.
D: For prevention, because you’re at 6–8 days a month and it’s impacting work, I recommend starting a daily preventive. Options: a beta blocker like propranolol; a tricyclic such as nortriptyline; topiramate; or CGRP blockers. Given your job needs crystal-clear thinking, I’d avoid topiramate due to cognitive side effects. Propranolol can cause fatigue and slow your heart rate. Nortriptyline at low dose can help sleep and headaches with less grogginess than amitriptyline.
P: Nortriptyline sounds like the compromise. Cost?
D: Generic and inexpensive.
P: Duly noted.
D: Start 10 mg at night for a week, then 20–25 mg if you feel okay. We reassess in 6–8 weeks. Goal is at least a 50% drop in migraine days.
P: I can live with that. If I feel too foggy in the mornings?
D: Message me. We can adjust the dose or switch to propranolol 20 mg twice daily. We’ll pick what your body tolerates.
P: How about supplements with decent evidence?
D: Magnesium glycinate 200–400 mg nightly and riboflavin 400 mg daily are reasonable. Main side effect is loose stools with magnesium—glycinate is easier on the stomach.
P: I’ll try those too.
D: Lifestyle levers help a lot. Practical moves: consistent sleep and wake times; don’t skip meals; hydrate; cap caffeine and keep it steady every day; short screen breaks—20-20-20 rule; dim or soften overhead lights; consider FL-41 tinted lenses for screens; gentle neck stretches.
P: I can ask the office for a desk lamp and turn off the fluorescents. And I’ll standardize the coffee.
D: Great. Keep a simple headache diary—date, time, severity, meds taken, possible trigger, and whether the acute meds worked. A spreadsheet is fine.
P: You’re speaking my language.
D: Two other notes. First, medication overuse: keep triptan days under 9 per month and NSAIDs under 15. Second, with aura there’s a small lifetime increase in stroke risk—higher if you smoke or have uncontrolled blood pressure. You don’t smoke; your BP is good. We’ll keep it that way.
P: Appreciate the straight talk. No smoking here. I’m frugal, not reckless.
D: If you need workplace accommodations—a note for flexible lighting, screen breaks, or a quiet space—I can write one.
P: That would help. My team’s supportive, but paper makes processes move.
D: Done. When a migraine starts, take rizatriptan 10 mg plus naproxen 500 mg, hydrate, dark room if you can. If nausea is bad, add metoclopramide.
P: Take at aura or pain onset. Limit to nine days a month. Got it.
D: Red flags—go to the ER or call: sudden “worst headache,” a new type that’s rapidly escalating, a headache with fever and stiff neck, weakness or trouble speaking, aura lasting over an hour, or a head injury.
P: Understood.
D: I’ll send in nortriptyline 10 mg nightly with instructions to increase after a week, rizatriptan 10 mg, naproxen 500 mg, and metoclopramide as needed. I’ll add a brief summary of lifestyle tips and a note for work.
P: Thank you. This feels…manageable. Like I finally put a framework around it.
D: Good. Let’s follow up in six weeks. Message me sooner if side effects hit or the plan isn’t working.
P: Will do. And, small win for me—asking for help is not my usual move.
D: It’s a smart move. See you soon, Marcus.
P: Thanks, Dr. Patel. I’ll start tonight and keep the log.
</dialogue>
</dialogue>

P: Uh, hi! Do I sit here or over there? Oh, sorry, yeah—I’ll sit here. Hi, Dr. Patel.
D: Hello Eli! It’s good to see you. How have you been feeling lately?
P: Umm… pretty good most days. But last week when I was practicing my dance—it’s like a really fast K-pop routine—I had to stop in the middle ’cause I started coughing. My chest kinda felt tight too. I told my mom, and she said we should come in.
D: I’m glad you did. Have you noticed the coughing and tightness happen at other times, too? Or mostly when you’re dancing?
P: Mostly when I’m dancing, yeah. Sometimes when we’re in gym at school, too, if we run a lot. It feels like I can’t get enough air, like someone’s squishing my lungs a little. Not always though, just some days.
D: I see. Does anything help when that happens? Do you use your inhaler?
P: Yeah. My mom brings it to all my dance stuff now. I used it last night after I finished my song—well, my routine, but I was listening to my song on repeat. The inhaler helps if I sit down and do it, but I wish I didn’t have to stop what I’m doing, you know?
D: I understand. How often have you needed to use your inhaler in the past week or so?
P: Ummm… three times since Sunday, I think? Monday, Wednesday, and then yesterday. I told my little sister I was like a steam train running out of puff, and she laughed and made chugga-chugga noises. She’s annoying, but funny sometimes.
D: Sounds like you two have a lot of fun together. Do you ever wake up at night because of coughing or trouble breathing?
P: Oh, just once this week. I think it was Tuesday? I barely remember ‘cause I was sleepy. But I coughed and went to get water. It stopped after that.
D: Thanks for telling me. Have you noticed if anything else makes it worse—like being outside, or when it’s cold?
P: Definitely cold air. Like, if I go out dancing with my friends when it’s cold, I get kinda wheezy faster. Not so much in the summer… unless there’s a lot of pollen or stuff flying around. I don’t like that.
D: That’s helpful to know. On days where you don’t dance or exercise a lot, do you still ever feel short of breath or cough?
P: Hm, not really. Only if my sister sprays her glitter hairspray near me—ugh, it’s so gross. Mostly it’s just when I’m moving and dancing a lot.
D: Okay. Let’s talk about your current asthma medicine. Are you taking it every day or just when you have symptoms?
P: I have the blue inhaler—wait, it’s albuterol, right?—that I use when it gets bad. I had a daily medicine too but I, um, kind of forgot to take it a couple times. My mom reminds me, but sometimes I just forget, especially if I’m late for practice.
D: That happens sometimes. It’s important to take your daily medicine even when you’re feeling okay. It helps prevent these episodes. Do you have any questions about your asthma or your medicines?
P: Oh! Does singing make it worse? I’m thinking about maybe signing up for the talent show, but what if my asthma gets weird on stage? Also, is there like a super inhaler for dancers? Or, I dunno, something cooler?
D: Singing can sometimes make you feel short of breath, but with good asthma control, you should be able to perform confidently. There isn’t a “super inhaler,” but we can work together to adjust your medicine routine so you can dance and sing without worrying as much. Would you like to talk about ways to remember your daily medicine?
P: Yeah, that would help. Mom says reminders on my tablet might work. I just get so into my music I forget about… everything!
D: That’s common! We can set up reminders together, and maybe your family can help too. Is there anything else worrying you about your asthma, or anything else you want to ask?
P: Ummm… sometimes I worry people will think I’m weird if I need my inhaler in front of them, or like, in the middle of a performance. But I don’t want to stop dancing. Not ever.
D: It’s very brave to talk about your worries, Eli. Lots of performers—even famous ones—manage asthma. With the right plan, you won’t have to stop doing what you love. If you want, I have some tips for using your inhaler quickly and discreetly. 
P: Really? Awesome. And—uh—do you know any doctors who can moonwalk? ‘Cause that’d be epic.
D: I might need some lessons from you first! Next time you’re here, maybe you can show me some moves.
P: Deal! Only if you promise not to use me as an example of “what not to do” at doctor school.
D: It’s a promise, Eli. Let’s get started on your asthma plan!
</dialogue>
</dialogue>
